title: Clerical fascism
text:
Clerical fascism (also clero-fascism or clerico-fascism) is an ideology that combines the political and economic doctrines of <a href="fascism">fascism</a> with <a href="clericalism">clericalism</a>. The term has been used to describe organizations and movements that combine religious elements with fascism, receive support from religious organizations which espouse sympathy for fascism, or fascist regimes in which clergy play a leading role.
History.
The term "clerical fascism" (clero-fascism or clerico-fascism) emerged in the early 1920s in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a>, referring to the faction of the Roman Catholic <a href="Italian%20People%27s%20Party%20%281919%E2%80%931926%29">Partito Popolare Italiano</a> which supported <a href="Benito%20Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a> and his régime; it was supposedly coined by <a href="Luigi%20Sturzo">Don Luigi Sturzo</a>, a priest and <a href="Christian%20democracy">Christian democrat</a> leader who opposed Mussolini and went into exile in 1924, although the term had also been used before Mussolini's <a href="March%20on%20Rome">March on Rome</a> in 1922 to refer to Catholics in Northern Italy who advocated a synthesis of Roman Catholicism and fascism.
Sturzo made a distinction between the "filofascists", who left the Catholic PPI in 1921 and 1922, and the "clerical fascists" who stayed in the party after the <a href="March%20on%20Rome">March on Rome</a>, advocating collaboration with the fascist government. Eventually, the latter group converged with Mussolini, abandoning the PPI in 1923 and creating the Centro Nazionale Italiano. The PPI was disbanded by the fascist régime in 1926.
The term has since been used by scholars seeking to contrast authoritarian-<a href="conservatism">conservative</a> clerical fascism with more radical variants. Christian fascists focus on internal religious politics, such as passing laws and regulations that reflect their view of <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a>. Radicalized forms of Christian fascism or "clerical fascism" (clero-fascism or clerico-fascism) were emerging on the far-right of the political spectrum in some European countries during the <a href="interwar%20period">interwar period</a> in the first half of the 20th century.
Fascist Italy.
In 1870 the newly formed <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a> annexed the remaining <a href="Papal%20States">Papal States</a>, depriving the Pope of his <a href="Temporal%20power%20%28papal%29">temporal power</a>. However, papal rule in Italy was later <a href="Lateran%20Treaty">restored</a> by the <a href="Fascist%20Italy%20%281922%E2%80%931943%29%23Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Fascist regime</a> (albeit on a greatly diminished scale) in 1929 as head of the <a href="Vatican%20City">Vatican City</a> state; under <a href="Mussolini">Mussolini</a>'s <a href="dictatorship">dictatorship</a>, Roman Catholicism became the <a href="state%20religion">state religion</a> of Fascist Italy.
In March 1929, a nationwide plebiscite was held to publicly endorse the <a href="Lateran%20Treaty">Lateran Treaty</a>. Opponents were intimidated by the fascist regime: the <a href="Azione%20Cattolica">Catholic Action</a> organisation ("Azione Cattolica") and Mussolini claimed that "no" votes were of those "few ill-advised <a href="Anti-clericalism">anti-clericals</a> who refuse to accept the Lateran Pacts". Nearly nine million Italians voted, or 90 per cent of the registered electorate, and only 136,000 voted "no".
Almost immediately after the signing of the Treaty, relations between Mussolini and the Church soured again. Mussolini "referred to Catholicism as, in origin, a minor sect that had spread beyond Palestine only because grafted onto the organization of the Roman empire." After the concordat, "he confiscated more issues of Catholic newspapers in the next three months than in the previous seven years." Mussolini reportedly came close to being <a href="Excommunication%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">excommunicated</a> from the Catholic Church around this time.
In 1938, the <a href="Italian%20Racial%20Laws">Italian Racial Laws</a> and "<a href="Manifesto%20of%20Race">Manifesto of Race</a>" were promulgated by the fascist regime, enforced to both <a href="The%20Holocaust%20in%20Italy">outlaw and persecute Italian Jews</a> and <a href="Protestantism%20in%20Italy">Protestant Christians</a>, especially <a href="Evangelicals">Evangelicals</a> and <a href="Pentecostals">Pentecostals</a>. Thousands of Italian Jews and a small number of Protestants died in the <a href="Nazi%20concentration%20camps">Nazi concentration camps</a>. 
In Jan. 1939, The Jewish National Monthly reports "the only bright spot in Italy has been the Vatican, where fine humanitarian statements by the Pope have been issuing regularly". When Mussolini's anti-Semitic decrees began depriving Jews of employment in Italy, Pius XI, on his own initiative, admitted Professor <a href="Vito%20Volterra">Vito Volterra</a>, a famous Italian Jewish mathematician, into the Pontifical Academy of Science.
Despite Mussolini's close alliance with Hitler's Germany, Italy did not fully adopt Nazism's genocidal ideology towards the Jews. The Nazis were frustrated by the Italian authorities' refusal to co-operate in the round-ups of Jews, and no Jews were deported prior to the formation of the <a href="Italian%20Social%20Republic">Italian Social Republic</a> following the <a href="Armistice%20of%20Cassibile">Armistice of Cassibile</a>. In the Italian-occupied <a href="Independent%20State%20of%20Croatia">Independent State of Croatia</a>, German envoy <a href="Siegfried%20Kasche">Siegfried Kasche</a> advised Berlin that Italian forces had "apparently been influenced" by Vatican opposition to German anti-Semitism. As anti-Axis feeling grew in Italy, the use of <a href="Vatican%20Radio">Vatican Radio</a> to broadcast papal disapproval of race murder and anti-Semitism angered the Nazis. Mussolini was overthrown in July 1943, the Germans moved to occupy Italy, and commenced a round-up of Jews.
Around 4% of <a href="Italian%20resistance%20movement">Resistance forces</a> were formally Catholic organisations, but Catholics dominated other "independent groups" such as the "<a href="Fiamme%20Verdi">Fiamme Verdi</a>" and "Osoppo" partisans, and there were also Catholic militants in the <a href="Garibaldi%20Brigades">Garibaldi Brigades</a>, such as <a href="Benigno%20Zaccagnini">Benigno Zaccagnini</a>, who later served as a prominent <a href="Christian%20Democracy%20%28Italy%29">Christian Democrat</a> politician. In Northern Italy, tensions between Catholics and <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Italy">communists</a> in the movement led Catholics to form the "Fiamme Verdi" as a separate brigade of Christian Democrats. After the war, the ideological divisions between former partisans re-emerged, becoming a hallmark of <a href="Politics%20of%20Italy%23History%20of%20the%20post-war%20political%20landscape">post-war Italian politics</a>.
Examples of clerical fascism.
Examples of political movements involving certain elements of clerical fascism include:
The <a href="National%20Union%20%28Portugal%29">National Union</a> in <a href="Estado%20Novo%20%28Portugal%29">Portugal</a> led by Prime Ministers <a href="Ant%C3%B3nio%20de%20Oliveira%20Salazar">António de Oliveira Salazar</a> and <a href="Marcelo%20Caetano">Marcelo Caetano</a> is not considered Fascist by historians such as <a href="Stanley%20G.%20Payne">Stanley G. Payne</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Gerard%20Gallagher">Thomas Gerard Gallagher</a>, <a href="Juan%20Jos%C3%A9%20Linz">Juan José Linz</a>, <a href="Ant%C3%B3nio%20Costa%20Pinto">António Costa Pinto</a>, <a href="Roger%20Griffin">Roger Griffin</a>, <a href="Robert%20Paxton">Robert Paxton</a> and <a href="Howard%20J.%20Wiarda">Howard J. Wiarda</a>, though it is considered Fascist by historians such as Manuel de Lucena, Jorge Pais de Sousa, Manuel Loff, and Hermínio Martins. One of Salazar's actions was to ban the National Syndicalists/Fascists. Salazar distanced himself from fascism and Nazism, which he criticized as a "pagan <a href="Caesarism">Caesarism</a>" that recognised neither legal nor moral limits.
Likewise, the <a href="Fatherland%20Front%20%28Austria%29">Fatherland Front</a> in <a href="Federal%20State%20of%20Austria">Austria</a> led by <a href="Catholicism%20in%20Austria">Austrian Catholic</a> Chancellors <a href="Engelbert%20Dollfuss">Engelbert Dollfuss</a> and <a href="Kurt%20Schuschnigg">Kurt Schuschnigg</a> is often not regarded as a fully fascist party. It has been called semi-Fascist and even imitation Fascist. Dollfuss was murdered by the Nazis, shot in his office by the SS and left to bleed to death. His regime did initially receive support from Fascist Italy, which formed the <a href="Stresa%20Front">Stresa Front</a> with the United Kingdom and France.
Nonetheless, scholars who accept the use of the term "clerical fascism" debate which of the listed examples should be dubbed "clerical fascist", with the Ustaše being the most widely included. In the examples cited above, the degree of official Catholic support and clerical influence over lawmaking and government varies. Moreover, several authors reject the concept of a "clerical fascist régime", arguing that an entire fascist régime does not become "clerical" if elements of the clergy support it, while others are not prepared to use the term "clerical fascism" outside the context of what they call the "fascist epoch", between the ends of the two <a href="world%20wars">world wars</a> (1918–1945).
Some scholars consider certain contemporary movements to be forms of clerical fascism, such as <a href="Christian%20Identity">Christian Identity</a> and <a href="Christian%20Reconstructionism">Christian Reconstructionism</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>; "the most virulent form" of <a href="Islamic%20fundamentalism">Islamic fundamentalism</a>, <a href="Islamism">Islamism</a>; and militant <a href="Hindu%20nationalism">Hindu nationalism</a> in <a href="India">India</a>.
The political theorist <a href="Roger%20Griffin">Roger Griffin</a> warns against the "hyperinflation of clerical fascism". According to Griffin, the use of the term "clerical fascism" should be limited to "the peculiar forms of politics that arise when religious clerics and professional theologians are drawn either into collusion with the "secular" ideology of fascism (an occurrence particularly common in <a href="interwar%20period">interwar</a> <a href="Europe">Europe</a>); or, more rarely, manage to mix a theologically illicit cocktail of deeply held religious beliefs with a fascist commitment to saving the nation or race from decadence or collapse". Griffin adds that "clerical fascism" "should never be used to characterize a political movement or a regime in its entirety, since it can at most be a faction within fascism", while he defines fascism as "a revolutionary, secular variant of ultranationalism bent on the total rebirth of society through human agency".
In the case of the <a href="Slovak%20State">Slovak State</a>, some scholars have rejected the use of the term clerical fascism as a label for the regime and they have particularly rejected its use as a label for <a href="Jozef%20Tiso">Jozef Tiso</a>. Slovak historian <a href="%C4%BDubom%C3%ADr%20Lipt%C3%A1k">Ľubomír Lipták</a> has argued that "clerofascism" is similar to <a href="Judeo-Bolshevism">Judeo-Bolshevism</a> because both movements mutually sought "to compromise one [component] with the other."
